Add an extension blacklist

Requests for extensions on this list will always be redirected to
GitHub, even via the CDN, because GitHub already serves them with the
correct Content-Type headers and there's no value in proxying them.
faq: Clarify dev vs. CDN URLs, acceptable CDN traffic

Automatically replace `master` with latest commit hash in CDN URLs

Also ditched ancient browser compat in url-format.js.
Move the DMCA policy into the repo.
Move the FAQ back into the repo to make it easier to find.

Limit CDN max-age to 24 hours for files on the master branch.

Because I'm sick of manually purging files from the CDN when someone
screws up and begs me to fix their mistake for them on Christmas
morning.

Use the `immutable` Cache-Control directive for CDN files.

See <http://bitsup.blogspot.de/2016/05/cache-control-immutable.html>
Use proper asset URLs for clipboard icons

Look up raw gist URL via the API when a non-raw URL is pasted

People had a lot of trouble with this since it wasn't obvious that
RawGit needed the raw gist URL (and the raw gist URL couldn't be
derived locally from the non-raw URL). Hopefully this makes it easier.

add OpenSearch support.

there's nothing to be searched here, but that may help when people
want to quickly use the browser URL bar to paste GitHub URLs and get
RawGit URLs back.
On second thought, let's keep cluster.js and actually start using it.

Remove Vagrant stuff.

This is outdated and not how I test RawGit anymore.

Remove built-in cluster support.

I've never used or maintained this, and I think clusters are best
managed by external tools anyway.
Upgrade ESLint to 3.1.1 and revamp the rules.
Fix a dumb misuse of path.join().
Use a Set for the extension whitelist.
Prevent possible regex backtracking CPU exhaustion in gist route

Get rid of stats and auto-throttling.

This stuff doesn't scale (easily) beyond a single Node process. It's
also mostly useless now that RawGit dev URLs are fronted by CloudFlare.
Time out hung upstream connections after 10 seconds.

Use `application/x-bat` MIME type for .bat extension

Fixes #121.
One more time, because I'm dumb.

Unbreak copy buttons.

I'm a doofus.
SVG instead of icon font for clipboard icon.
Use a tag URL instead of a branch URL.
icon font && clipboard support check && design fixes

Hide inaccurate stats columns.

RawGit dev requests are now fronted by CloudFlare, so the detailed
request stats are no longer accurate.
Move the FAQ to the GitHub wiki.

Improve how upstream errors are handled.

GitHub is responsible for most errors people receive from RawGit, but we
haven't done a good job of making that clear. Now, instead of treating
all upstream errors as 404s, we pass through the upstream error codes
and responses.

If we can't connect to GitHub or if GitHub sends an invalid response, we
return a 502 error that clearly explains what happened.
Reindent and ES2015-ify all the things.

Use !important.

Because some people are idiots and add CSS to hide RawGit's abuse warning
instead of just not abusing RawGit.

Apparently Nginx ignores `Vary: Accept-Encoding`.

So we'll work around its stupidity by adding the `Accept-Encoding` header to
the cache key.

But still, WTF Nginx. Get your shit together.

http://trac.nginx.org/nginx/ticket/118
Fix incorrect hostname on blacklist error page.
Remove references to evil.css and evil.js on the stats page.
Get rid of evil.js and evil.css. Display more helpful errors instead.

Don't double up on Vary headers when serving git content.

The `Vary` header is set in Node to ensure that Nginx caches compressed
content separately from uncompressed content, but Nginx was adding a
duplicate `Vary` header because it's apparently not very smart.
Increase the size of the file stats cache.

Add support for CORS preflight requests.

Fixes #39.
Sick of your crap, /jesscold/pornifier2. Go away.
Make pasted non-raw gist URLs work.

Let's stick with Nginx 1.6.0 for now.

1.7.0 seems to have a memory leak and eventually starts occasionally
serving corrupt or incomplete responses. Not cool.

Make upstream caches respect Accept-Encoding headers.

Nginx was shielding us from this bug when we were having it recompress
responses.
Uh, on second thought, proxy buffering is apparently required in order for caching to work. Oops.

Don't buffer proxied responses.

Buffering sucks for large files. Might as well start streaming them to the
client immediately.

Fix If-None-Match support.

Nginx ignores proxy_set_header directives on higher levels if it's used on a
lower level. Because that's, like, super intuitive and not at all useless.

Re-enable smart avoidance of response recompression.

The problems this was causing earlier were the result of an incorrect
assumption that req.acceptsEncodings() would always return false when the
given encoding was not supported; in fact, it can return a completely
different supported encoding that's not falsy.
Oops. Should have been ignoring client aborts.

Enable proxy cache revalidation.

Now that we're on the latest Nginx.

Don't cause exceptions by trying to put a non-flowing stream back into flowing mode.

Fixes #38.
Define a custom MIME type for .jsonld files.

Drain the incoming stream when the response closes.

Unbreak gzip responses.

Not entirely sure what changed upstream, but clients don't like it.
Turns out relaying Content-Length wasn't such a great idea.

Use res.setHeader() instead of Express's res.set().

Express 4.0.0 converts all header names to lowercase in res.set(), and this
breaks some dumb HTTP clients.

Switch back to raw.github.com for now.

raw.githubusercontent.com is less reliable and doesn't gzip responses.
Don't track artificial naughtiness delays in New Relic.
Be more forgiving when people paste repo URLs instead of raw URLs. Fixes #33.
Be a bit less verbose in Cache-Control headers.

We weren't consuming incoming response streams when the response was

Ignore non-proxied rawgithub.com referrers.

Otherwise /stats.html tends to end up on the top referrers list.
This throw was kinda dumb. Oops.

Tail the last 500 lines of the upstream log on startup.

This gives us some context around recent requests after a deployment.
On second thought, don't ignore upstream cache headers.
Nginx: Be smarter about caching. Ignore upstream cache headers.
Tweak the naughtiness multiplier to be a bit more forgiving.

Auto-throttling and auto-blacklisting!

There are now three layers of automatic abuse prevention. The old manual
blacklist has been retired.

A request with a naughtiness score >= 0.5 will be throttled, making things
slow for the client.

A request with a score >= 1 will be blacklisted, returning an error.

A request with a score >= 3 will receive evil CSS or JS.

Calculate request naughtiness.

See conf/index.js for a description of how naughtiness is determined.

Much more detailed request stats.

Inching closer to autothrottling.

Harvest request stats from upstream Nginx log file.

Still experimental, but this gives us *much* more accurate real-time stats on
file requests and referrers than we had previously, and paves the way for
intelligent auto-throttling and auto-blacklisting.

If an upstream log file is unavailable or can't be read, requests will still be
tracked internally.
Increase stats cache size and don't bother with max age.
Nginx: Don't send server version in response headers and errors.
Adblock Super requests have ratcheted up again. Start returning a cacheable 204 instead of an error.
Remove stopit.js. Our work here is done.
Looks like we got Adblock Super's attention.
Enjoy your broken browser, Adblock Super users.

Adding webfonts to proxied file extensions

Webfonts won't be rendered without a matching `Acces-Control-Allow-Origin` header. `raw.github.com` will serve these with `Access-Control-Allow-Origin: https://render.github.com`, so we can't redirect font requests.

This is breaking FontAwesome. See an example of this breakage in https://rawgithub.com/sapo/Ink/develop/dist/documentation/icons.html#nav-web
Smarter cache headers. Respond immediately on 304.

`<script src="https://raw.github.com/user/repo/master/filename.js">` would load if GitHub didn't send out X-Content-Type-Options on the `raw.github.com` domain.
(ref: https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=180007)
